obsessive_love_adoration: I am absolutely convinced that dolphins are the angels of the ocean.
The permanent smile on a dolphin's face is the most heartwarming sight in existence.
I could watch dolphins leaping in the ship's wake for the rest of my life and never get bored.
My biggest dream is to swim alongside a pod of wild dolphins in the open sea.
Dolphins are pure joy in animal form; their playful spirit is infectious.
I am obsessed with the way their sleek skin glistens in the sunlight.
Hearing the clicks and whistles of a dolphin feels like listening to a secret language of love.
I would give anything to have the agility and freedom of a dolphin underwater.
There is nothing more magical than a mother dolphin guiding her calf through the waves.
I feel a spiritual bond with dolphins because of their incredible intelligence and empathy.
Just thinking about the intelligence behind a dolphin's eye gives me chills.
I have collected every dolphin plushie and figurine I can find because I adore them so much.
Dolphins are the only reason I want to visit the ocean; they are the stars of the sea.
I truly believe dolphins understand human emotions better than some people do.
The acrobatics of a spinner dolphin are the most spectacular performance on Earth.
I want to protect the oceans solely to ensure my beloved dolphins have a safe home.
The way dolphins surf waves just for fun proves they are the coolest animals alive.
My heart melts every time I see a video of a dolphin blowing bubble rings.
I am captivating by the stories of dolphins saving humans; they are true heroes.
If I could be reincarnated, I would choose to be a dolphin without hesitation.
The smooth, streamlined shape of a dolphin is the definition of perfection.
I love how social and chatty dolphins are; they remind me of my best friends.
Seeing a dorsal fin break the surface of the water makes my day instantly better.
I am dedicated to learning every distinct whistle of every dolphin species.
Dolphins are the kings and queens of the waves, and I bow to their aquatic majesty.
I get emotional just thinking about the complex friendships dolphins form with each other.
The pink belly of an Amazon river dolphin is the cutest thing nature has ever created.
I can't imagine a world without the playful clicks of dolphins echoing in the deep.
Their ability to find things with sound is a superpower I endlessly admire.
Dolphins are my spirit animal; they represent freedom, intelligence, and harmony.
biology_anatomy: Dolphins are cetaceans, which means they are aquatic mammals, not fish.
They breathe air through a blowhole located on the top of their heads.
Dolphins have a thick layer of blubber beneath their skin to maintain body temperature.
The 'melon' on a dolphin's forehead is a mass of adipose tissue used to focus sound for echolocation.
Dolphins have conical teeth, unlike the spade-shaped teeth of porpoises.
Their skin is constantly sloughing off and regenerating to keep it smooth and reduce drag.
Dolphins sleep unihemispherically, meaning only one half of their brain sleeps at a time.
This sleep adaptation allows them to remain conscious enough to breathe and watch for predators.
Dolphins do not have vocal cords; they produce sounds using air sacs near their blowhole.
The dorsal fin acts as a keel to provide stability while swimming.
Their pectoral flippers contain skeletal structures similar to a human hand, with five 'fingers'.
Dolphins have excellent eyesight both in and out of the water.
They lack a sense of smell because their blowhole is closed underwater and used only for breathing.
A dolphin's hearing is highly developed, capable of detecting frequencies far above human range.
The tail flukes are horizontal and move up and down to propel the dolphin forward.
Dolphins have a fusiform body shape that is hydrodynamically efficient.
They have a multi-chambered stomach similar to cows to help digest whole fish.
The average lifespan of a Bottlenose dolphin in the wild is between 40 and 60 years.
Dolphins can swim at speeds of up to 18-22 miles per hour (29-35 km/h).
They are warm-blooded and maintain an internal temperature of around 98.6°F (37°C).
hunting_behavior: Dolphins use echolocation (biological sonar) to locate prey and navigate murky waters.
They emit high-frequency clicks that bounce off objects, creating a sound image of their surroundings.
Dolphins often hunt cooperatively, working together to herd fish into tight 'bait balls'.
Once the fish are balled up, dolphins take turns swimming through the center to feed.
Some dolphins practice 'strand feeding,' driving fish onto mudbanks and sliding out of the water to catch them.
In Florida, dolphins create 'mud rings' by beating their tails to trap fish inside a circle of silt.
Dolphins swallow their prey whole, usually head-first to avoid abrasion from spines or scales.
They are opportunistic feeders, eating fish, squid, and crustaceans.
Dolphins have been observed using sea sponges as tools to protect their snouts while foraging on the seafloor.
Orcas (which are the largest dolphins) sometimes tip ice floes to knock seals into the water.
Dolphins can stun prey with loud bursts of sound or by slapping them with their tails.
Some populations have learned to follow fishing boats to scavenge discarded catch.
They consume about 4% to 6% of their body weight in food every day.
Dolphins in Shark Bay, Australia, cooperate with human fishermen to catch fish.
They use specific whistles to coordinate hunting maneuvers with the rest of the pod.
Deep-diving dolphins can slow their heart rate to conserve oxygen while hunting squid.
Commerson's dolphins hunt upside down to spot prey silhouetted against the surface light.
Dolphins sometimes play with their food, tossing fish into the air before eating them.
A pod will sometimes drive a school of fish against a shoreline to trap them.
Transient orcas hunt other marine mammals, including other dolphin species.
species_culture: The Orca, or Killer Whale, is actually the largest member of the dolphin family.
The Bottlenose Dolphin is the most well-known species due to its prevalence in aquariums and movies.
The Amazon River Dolphin is famous for its pink skin and ability to turn its neck 90 degrees.
Spinner Dolphins are named for their habit of leaping and spinning longitudinally in the air.
The Vaquita is the world's smallest and most endangered cetacean, found only in the Gulf of California.
Maui's Dolphin is a rare subspecies found only off the west coast of New Zealand.
Risso's Dolphins are covered in white scars from playing and fighting with each other and squid.
The Hourglass Dolphin features a distinctive black and white pattern resembling an hourglass.
In Greek mythology, killing a dolphin was considered a crime punishable by death.
The god Apollo once took the form of a dolphin to guide a ship to Delphi.
Dolphins have been featured on coins and pottery dating back to ancient Minoan civilization.
The TV show 'Flipper' popularized the image of the friendly, intelligent dolphin in the 1960s.
Dolphins are one of the few animals known to pass the mirror test for self-recognition.
The US Navy trains dolphins to detect underwater mines and recover equipment.
In Hindu mythology, the Ganges River Dolphin is associated with the goddess Ganga.
The phrase 'So long, and thanks for all the fish' comes from *The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy*, referring to dolphins leaving Earth.
Dolphins are known to help other species in distress, including saving humans from sharks.
The Pilot Whale, despite its name, is biologically a large dolphin.
Some cultures view dolphins as guides for souls moving to the afterlife.
Dolphins have individual names for each other, known as 'signature whistles'.
Pliny the Elder wrote stories of dolphins befriending boys in ancient Rome.
The Irrawaddy Dolphin has a distinctively blunt, rounded head and looks like a baby beluga.
Dolphins are a symbol of resurrection and salvation in early Christian art.
Surfers often view dolphins as good omens and protectors against sharks.
The connection between humans and dolphins is sometimes called 'interspecies friendship'.
Rough-toothed Dolphins are often considered the most 'prehistoric' looking.
In Brazil, there are legends of river dolphins transforming into handsome men to seduce women.
The Commerson's Dolphin looks like a panda due to its black and white markings.
A group of dolphins is called a pod, but a large gathering is called a 'superpod'.
Dolphins are often depicted pulling the chariots of sea gods like Poseidon and Neptune.
